pullRequest.body:
Feat: Add `Congruent` in `Topology.MetricSpace.Congruence`

This is a port of:

https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/18214

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: @jsm28 Here is the first PR from the bunch.  There wasn't any comments from you about this file in the previous PR.  Let me know if there are any modifications that you would like me to make to the port.
Perhaps @JovanGerb has something to say about this definition?

When talking about congruent or similar triangles, it's really important to distinguish triangle ABC from triangle ACB (the two are congruent only if the triangle is isosceles). I'm confident that indexed families are correct for defining congruences, and sets would not be correct.

There are (at least) two notions that are equivalent in a Euclidean space:

- the one introduced in this PR, `∀ i j, edist (f i) (f j) = edist (g i) (g j)`
- `∃ e : X ≃ᵢ Y, e ∘ f = g`

I don't know which one is called "congruent" in general case.

There was a long discussion in the thread https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Euclidean.20Geometry about the merits of the two approaches for defining congruence (equal pairwise distances versus existence of an isometric equivalence). Some evidence was found in that thread that the more general notion (equal pairwise distances) is indeed used in the literature between different metric spaces that don't have an isometric equivalence.

In any case, once things move from the general setup in metric spaces to more specific Euclidean applications, the fact that equal distances implies an isometric equivalence in Euclidean spaces with the same finite dimension (or various other such Euclidean cases) will be a natural result to prove early on (that thread has some discussion of how `inner_weightedVSub` / `dist_affineCombination` might be used to prove such results).
IMHO, this should be discussed in the docstring.

> IMHO, this should be discussed in the docstring.

Doc-string updated.

### PR summary [6d7dbd034e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/7478/commits/6d7dbd034e4286c1e5a6b9f4a2a3cf874a5f5f89)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.MetricSpace.Congruence` (new file)|894|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Congruent`
`+ _root_.congruence_comm`
`+ congruent_iff_dist_eq`
`+ congruent_iff_edist_eq`
`+ congruent_iff_nndist_eq`
`+ congruent_iff_pairwise_dist_eq`
`+ congruent_iff_pairwise_edist_eq`
`+ congruent_iff_pairwise_nndist_eq`
`+ dist_eq`
`+ edist_eq`
`+ index_equiv`
`+ index_map`
`+ nndist_eq`
`+ of_dist_eq`
`+ of_edist_eq`
`+ of_nndist_eq`
`+ of_pairwise_dist_eq`
`+ of_pairwise_edist_eq`
`+ of_pairwise_nndist_eq`
`+ pairwise_dist_eq`
`+ pairwise_edist_eq`
`+ pairwise_nndist_eq`
`+ refl`
`+ symm`
`+ trans`
`++++++++++++ _`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

I've cleaned up the material in this PR, including removing the `congruence_map` material that seemed to be responsible for many of the issues and not needed for the definitions here to be useful, and I think it's now ready for review again.

@jsm28 can you please mark conversations as resolved if you think your action is sufficient to resolve them?

@PatrickMassot ping because this is assigned to you and it's now on the queue.
I was leaving an opportunity for the original reviewer to consider if they agree that those comments were resolved, but I've now marked them as resolved myself.
bors merge

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13636609661/job/38116856361)

```suggestion
def Congruent (v₁ : ι → P₁) (v₂ : ι → P₂) [PseudoEMetricSpace P₁]
```
Does it mean that we can't deal with congruence and category theory at the same time?
I don't know as I haven't done much with category theory in mathlib.  Maybe @jsm28 knows?

I have no idea what the effects of this notation would be on using congruence together with category theory. (I do expect to have a use for category theory in *combinatorial* geometry - it's how mathlib handles compactness arguments - though probably not for congruence of families of points in that combinatorial geometry.)
This does not match the implementation that uses indexed families of points.
The module doc string now refers to indexed families.
Please remove the unneeded parentheses that make the definition harder to read.
I have I hope now removed all the excessive parentheses.

```suggestion
    Congruent v₁ v₂ ↔ ∀ i₁ i₂ : ι, edist (v₁ i₁) (v₁ i₂) = edist (v₂ i₁) (v₂ i₂) :=
  Iff.rfl
```
Please review every line you wrote to remove obfuscation parentheses. Also search and replace all your `fun … => …` to `fun … ↦ …`.
I've also changed everything here to use `↦`.
Are you aware of the `peel` tactic? I’m not saying you must use it instead of `forall₂_congr` but in more complicated cases it is a lot easier than wrestling those lemmas.
Here you can probably use `exact_mod_cast h hn`. Again this is not a request for change, only information for you.
I'm now using `exact_mod_cast` where applicable (this particular case has become an `iff` with `exact_mod_cast Iff.rfl` used in the proof).

```suggestion
    simp only [dist_nndist] at h
    exact_mod_cast h hn)
```
Also now an `iff` using `exact_mod_cast Iff.rfl`.
You can use dot notation here.
Now using dot notation, along with being stated for a general `EquivLike` and marked `@[simp]`.
This definition has nothing to do with congruences, right?

I've removed this definition and associated API. This definition indeed would belong somewhere more general, and the consequent fact about isometries of subtypes for the two ranges is probably of limited use (certainly what I think is more useful in the Euclidean case is the ability to extend to an affine isometry of the entire spaces spanned by the indexed families of points, and thus to apply lemmas that map other geometrical definitions, including constructing points not in the original families, across isometries).

```suggestion
  ext
```
This is part of the material I've removed.

```suggestion
  funext <| map_comp_apply h
```
This is part of the material I've removed.
Why not using the Congruent namespace? This would allow a lot more dot notation, right?
I've renamed the namespace.
Please merge all those `rw`.
This is part of the material I've removed.
could you refer in the docstring to the fact that these are aliases? something along the lines of "this is an alias of the forwards/backwards direction of `[___]`"?
I've added such information to the doc strings.
same here?
I've added such information to the doc strings here as well.
